PUBLIC SERVICE MUTUAL PROVIDENT ASSOCIATION : BUILDING 0053/08 01.
asked the Minister of Finance and Planning,:
(i) the Public Service Mutual Provident Associa-tion (PSMPA) is a century old statutory finan-cial institution incorporated under PSMPA Ordinance No.5 of 1891;
(ii) it is managed by a Committee consisting of President to the Committee, two nominated members appointed by the Secretary to the Treasury and 11 elected Committee members; and
(iii) a building for its office had been purchased at Rs. 48 million?

(b) Will he state whether Rs. 7 million was kept as a retainer money till the vendor would obtain for the PSMPA absolute ownership of the pur-chased property within one month from the Commission of National Housing according to the agreement No.2921 entered into between the purchaser (PSMPA) and vendor?
(i) the absolute ownership of the property has not yet been obtained for the PSMPA though over 3 years had elapsed, as pointed out by Auditor-General in his report on PSMPA Ac-counts for 2006; and
(ii) Rs. 5 million out of the retainer money has been paid out for reasons unknown? (d) Will he take necessary action to hold a public inquiry in this regard?
( - , , ) (The Hon. Ranjith SiyambalapitityaMinister of State Reve-nue and Finace and Deputy Minister of Finance and Planning) , . () (i) . (ii) . (iii) . () . () (i) 2921 . 2921 .
( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) , ()(iii) 48 . ? , , ? ( ) (The Hon. Ranjith Siyambalapititya) , . . /174/2007/ 40 .
asked the Minister of Higher Education :

(a) Will he inform this House the international rank-ings obtained for the Universities of Colombo, Sri Jayewardenepura, Peradeniya, Moratuwa and Jaffna in the decades beginning from 1960 to 2000 and from 2000 to-date, separately? (b) Will he state
(i) whether they have got foreign lecturers on a reciprocal basis; and
(ii) if so, the date that the last lecturer came and the Universities they came to within the last two years? (c) Will he also state
(i) the cost per student and per faculty in each University for the last five years on per year basis;
(ii) the number of students who have hostel facili-ties;
(iii) whether it is provided free or have the students got to pay;
(iv) the selection criteria to provide hostel facilities;
(v) the alternate arrangement made for students who do not have hostel facilities; and
(vi) the long - term strategy been adopted to pro-vide accommodations for all students?
(d) Will he inform for the last five years per Univer-sity and per year basis
(i) the number of foreign students admitted to uni-versities in Sri Lanka; and
(ii) their country and the revenue we earned? (e) If not, why?
( () . . - ) (The Hon. (Prof.) W. A. Wiswa Warnapala - Minister of Higher Education)

LOCAL AND FOREIGN PUBLIC DEBT : DETAILS 0124/08 3.
(i) , (ii) , (iii) , (iv) , (v) (vi) , (vii) , (viii) , (ix) , () , 05 ? () , ? asked the Minister of Finance and Planning, :

(a) Will he inform this House the total public debt outstanding as Local and Foreign debt sepa-rately (i) at the end of each year from 1948 to 1994; and (ii) at the end of each year from 1995 to 2007 and in 2008 to-date? (b) Will he inform this House the total debt amorti-zation (Capital+Interest) per year basis as per period mentioned in (i) and (ii) above? (c) Will he state the total debt of the following insti-tutions and countries as at year 1948 to 2003, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007 and 2008 to-date along with the average interest cost for the loans given (i) World Bank (ii) IMF (International Monetary Fund) (iii) ADB (Asian Development Bank) (iv) JBIC (Japan Bank for International Coop-eration) (v) USA (United State of America) (vi) Japan (vii) EU Countries (viii) India and (ix) China? (d) Will he also state the per capita debt compared against per capita earnings for the last 05 years on year basis? (e) If not, why?

: : MINISTRY OF SPECIAL PROJECTS : RECURRENT AND CAPITAL EXPENDITURE 0606/08 4. . . .

asked the Minister of Finance and Planning, : (a) Is he aware that funds were allocated for the Ministry of Special Projects through the Supplementary Estimate No.01 of 2007? (b) Will he submit to this House (i) the date on which the spending of the sum of Rs. 37,500,000/- which was allocated for recurrent expenditure, was commenced; (ii) the amount spent as at 31st December 2007; (iii) whether purchases have been made using recurrent expenditure; (iv) if so, the names of the items that have been purchased and the prices at which they were purchased; (v) separately, the amounts allocated for each project out of the provisions of capital expenditure of Rs. 10,800,000/-; (vi) the amount spent out of the aforesaid sum of money; and (vii) separately, the amount allocated and the amount spent for each project? (c) If not, why?

: : FISHERMEN AFFECTED DUE TO CYCLONE : RELIEF TO FAMILIES
() , ? asked the Minister of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources, :
(a) Is he aware that some fishermen perished as a result of the cyclonic condition that occurred in the Southern and Western costal areas, on the night of 22.07.2008?

(b) Will he inform this House (i) the number of fishermen who died and the number of fishermen who disappeared as a result of the aforesaid cyclonic condition; (ii) their names and addresses; (iii) the number of fishing vessels that were destroyed;

(iv) the names and addresses of the owners of those vessels; (v) the relief that was provided to the families of those who disappeared and those who died; and (vi) the relief that has been provided to repair the damaged fishing vessels and fishing gear? (c) If not, why?

asked the Minister of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources, : (a) Will he inform this House of the name and the address of the owner of the hotel named Lighthouse which has been constructed very close to the sea, at Devinuwara South Grama Niladhari Division in Devinuwara Divisional Secretarys Division?

(b) Is he aware that the provisions of Coast Conservation Act have been violated in locating this hotel? (c) Will he inform this House, (i) the name of the department from which a permit should be obtained, if a certain construction is to be carried out on the sea beach; (ii) whether a permit has been granted for the aforesaid construction accordingly; and (iii) the name of the person who held the relevant Ministerial portfolio at that time? (d) Will he admit that the aforesaid construction is illegal? (e) if it is illegal, will he state the measures that will be taken in this regard? (f) If not, why?

(a) Will he inform this House (i) the number of reservoirs in our country where freshwater fisheries industry is carried out; (ii) the number of fishermen and the number of families engaged in that fishing industry; and (iii) the number of fishing vessels in use for freshwater fisheries industry? (b) Will he state the steps that have been taken by the Government to promote freshwater fisheries industry? (c) If not, why?

HOUSES CLOSE TO NAMPAMUNUWA DIALOG COMMUNICATION TOWER: DAMAGE TO ELECTRICAL APPLIANCES 0885/08 10.

() (i) , (ii) , (iii) ? () ? () , ? asked the Minister of Posts and Telecommunication,: (a) Is he aware that (i) the Dialog communication tower built at Nampamunuwa, Piliyandala is located at a densely populated area; and (ii) the domestic electric circuits, electronic appliances and telephones in the houses located close to this tower have been severely damaged by lightening on or near 29.06.2008? (b) Will he admit the fact that petitions signed by the villagers regarding this incident have been referred to the Telecommunications Regulatory Commission, the Dialog Company and other responsible institutions? (c) Will he inform this House (i) of the factors considered when granting approval for the construction of this telecommunication tower; (ii) of the institutions from which approval has to be obtained for this; and (iii) whether approval has been granted by those institutions for the construction of the said tower? (d) Will he take necessary action to pay compensation for the damage that has been caused to the electrical appliances in those houses? (e) If not, why?

() , ? asked the Minister of Local Government and Provincial Councils, : (a) Will he inform this House (i) of the percentages of rates of Assessment Tax to be charged for the year 2008, as approved by the Urban Council of Kesbewa; (ii) of the basis on which those rates were determined; and (iii) whether the valuation officers of the said Urban Council have visited the entire area and obtained a correct valuation? (b) Will he admit that this value of rates is an exorbitant amount? (c) If so, will he state the steps that will be taken to rectify it? (d) If not, why?

: : DEVELOPMENT LOTTERIES BOARD : RENT OF OFFICE

() , ? asked the Minister of Finance and Planning, : (a) Will he submit to this House (i) the amount of money spent by the Development Lotteries Board to purchase a land and a building at Union Place; and (ii) the year in which it was done? (b) Will he state (i) the period of time for which the building which housed the then office was used with the payment of a rent after purchasing the above mentioned land and the building; (ii) the monthly rent paid for the aforesaid building; (iii) the loss thus incurred by the Board as a result of it; and (iv) the measures that were taken against the officers who are responsible for these financial losses? (c) If not, why?

. . Question ordered to stand down. , , : , , : MADAHAPOLA, MEDAKANDA, AND PARAGAHAELA LANDS : OWNERSHIP 0652/08 05. . .
( - . . - ) (The Hon. Bimal Ratnayake on behalf of The Hon. M.D. Namal Karunaratne) , (3) :
? () 50 ? () (i) , (ii) , , , (iii) , (iv) ? () , ? asked the Minister of Lands and Land Development,:

(a) Will he submit to this House of a detailed report of the Government lands and private lands in Madahapola, Medakande and the mountainous area of Paragahaela in the Polpithigama Divisional Secretarys Division in the Kurunegala District and the legal position with regard to the ownership of the lands of the farmers residing in the Madahapola, Medakanda and Paragahaela Grama Niladhari Divisions?

(b) Is he aware of the fact that a certain person is making arrangements to evict residents from a land extent of 50 acres in Madahapola and Medakanda Grama Niladhari Divisions, claiming that those lands belong to him?

(c) Will he state (i) whether, a private land of the aforesaid type is situated in that particular Grama Niladhari Division; (ii) if such a land is situated there, the extent and the nature of that land; (iii) the pedigree of the said land from its first owner to the present owner; and (iv) whether alternative lands will be provided to the residents of the aforesaid Grama Niladhari Divisions if a certain private land owner is planning to evict them? (d) If not, why?

(b) Will he state the number of officers serving in the North Western Province on voluntary basis in relation to each institution? (c) If not, why?

() DESHAMANYA RAVINDRA WANIGASEKARA FOUNDATION (INCORPORATION) BILL ( ) (The Hon. Dayasiri Jayasekara) , : " ." ( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) . . Seconded. . , . 47(5) .

, . , , . . 47 (5) , . Question put, and agreed to. Bill accordingly read the First time, and ordered to be printed. The Bill stood referred, under Standing Order No. 47(5), to the Minister of Social Services and Social Welfare for report.

( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) Sir, I rise to a point of Order. ( ) (Mr. Speaker) . ( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) Sir, I rise to a point of Order. I am sure you will agree that under Article 42 of the Constitution, the President and the Cabinet are responsible to Parliament. Furthermore, under Article 43(1), Sir, a specific Cabinet Minister is held responsible for discharging the Cabinet responsibility through Parliament. It is the accepted norm that in Parliament, you will be telling and revealing the truth because it is on behalf of the people. Mr. Speaker, I get up at this moment further with the Constitutional support buttressed by Standing Orders 84 and 85. Yesterday, the Minister, the Hon.Gamini Lokuge stated in this House a factually incorrect statement. I am at this particular moment taking full responsibility because the Prime Minister is here. I would not have taken it up if not for the Prime Minister because I know how the Leader of the Opposition and Prime Minister yesterday worked hand-in-glove and we appreciate the actions taken by the Prime Minister after the incident. Mr. Speaker, the website "guardian.co.uk" reports today "Warning of attacks on Sri Lanka cricket team was ignored". An article in the website "guardian.co.uk" reported by Mr. Saeed Shah in Lahore states, I quote: Police and administration officials met on 23 January to assess the threat, but before action could be taken, the government of Punjab province -of which Lahore is the capital - run by the party of the former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, was dismissed, following a court ruling. It further states, I quote: Intelligence reports said there might be an attack on the cricket team, said Pervez Rashid, a senior member of the sacked Punjab government. Furthermore, Hon. Prime Minister, the former cricketer and Pakistani politician in fame, Mr. Imran Khan has said, I quote: Its the government of Punjab which is responsible for this, because it is shocking - the sort of security they provided the Sri Lankan team after having given them guarantees that all the security concerns would be taken care of. A normal minister in Pakistan. would have got better security than was provided to the Sri Lankans. Hon. Prime Minister, why am I referring to this? As you know, the cricket team is being spoken of by everybody, not only in Sri Lanka, but around the world. "The Sunday Observer" of 28th December, 2008 states that the President and the Foreign Minister had looked into this matter and had given full approval. Hon. Prime Minister, the Indians who are even today saying IPL

should be cancelled in India, could not go to Pakistan. The Australians and the New Zealanders did not go to Pakistan. Hon. Prime Minister, the new organizer who has been appointed to Kotte, the Foreign Minister, has told untruths to the Cabinet. The Sports Minister also told us untruths yesterday by saying that all matters were looked into. I do not want to trouble you because you have enough trouble in your hands. But, the information that is being given to this House should be reliable. We have been supporting you all the way on many issues. When we raised this in Parliament yesterday, there was an uproar which was unfairly treated against us. What is the action taken when it is exposed in your own newspaper, "The Sunday Observer"? It is being mentioned by people of fame like Imran Khan. Furthermore, the information given by the Cabinet after the incident is also not true. Hon. Prime Minister, there has to be some concrete action taken. When the entire world knew that Pakistan was having problems; Nawaz Sharif was sacked; when security was assessed and when it was said that the Sri Lankan team was under threat, why should our cricket team be exposed to such threat? I do not want to make it a political thing. This cricket team is yours and ours like the armed forces. Today, some people try to think that the armed forces is part of the SLFP. But, the UNP and the SLFP are all there. So, I would greatly appreciate if the Prime Minister would take cognizance of this fact. ( ) (Mr. Speaker) . ( ) (The Hon. JAYALATH JAYAWARDENA MBBS, FICS, MD Member of Parliament Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka February 20, 2009 H E Shri Alok Prasad High Commissioner for India in Sri Lanka Indian High Commission 36 - 38 Galle Road Colombo 3 Dear Your Excellency Expression of sincere gratitude to the Government of India With reference to the telephone conversation I had with you today. I would like to thank you personally for assisting and making arrangements to import the most widely used, pain killing injection called Pethidine. There has been a very severe shortage of Pethidine injections in Sri Lanka for the last couple of weeks. As you are aware, this strong pain killing drug is being used to reduce pain in cases of trauma, accidents and injuries inflicted on the battle front. Therefore, there is a great demand for this injection in the hospitals of the war-torn areas of Sri Lanka. I would also like to thank you for facilitating the basic humanitarian needs and medicines to Sri Lanka from India. As an Assistant Secretary of the UNP in charge of Human Rights and Relief, let me express our sincere thanks and gratitude to the Government and people of India for assisting the people of Sri Lanka by providing the basic humanitarian needs and medicines.

Assuring you of my best services and attention at all times, Yours sincerely Dr. Jayalath Jayawardana, M P Assistant Secretary, UNP in charge of Human Rights & Relief Secretary General of Parliamentarians for Human Rights Res : No. 555, Wewala Church Road, Official Res : 26B, Samit Flats Weligamapitiya, Ja - Ela, Jawatte Road, Colombo 05, Sri Lanka. Sir, then I quote from the "Daily News" of 2nd March, 2009: A UN Security Council on Friday received a briefing by Under Secretary General Sir John Holmes who visited Sri Lanka at President Mahinda Rajapaksas invitation last week. The briefing did not result in a ceasefire call to Sri Lanka from the Security Council, but general agreement that the LTTE must lay down arms and ease suffering of civilians. Sir John Holmes told reporters that humanitarian concerns about the people held captive by the LTTE remains a major concern while the concerns about IDPs who have already come to cleared areas seem less than what was feared for. ? , , . . , .

. . . , , . , . . . I would also like to quote from an article published in the Sunday Island of 1st March, 2009. It states, I quote: LTTE forcibly holding civilians No genocide in Sri Lanka - HRW The Sri Lankan government is not committing genocide in the North, said Charu Lata Hogg of Human Rights Watch.

It is the LTTE which is forcibly holding innocent civilians as a human shield and shoot at them when they try to flee. There are certainly international guidelines which have to be met in a conflict situation. Sri Lanka cannot just be accused of genocide. . . . . ; . . ; . , . . , , GSP plus ; ; ; . . ( ) (The Hon. Athauda Seneviratne) ; . . , , , , . . . , , , , , . . ; . . , , . . - - . , ? ? . -- . . . ( ) (The Presiding Member) . ... . 20 . [. . 3.25] . . . ( . . . ) (The Hon. A. M. M. Naoshaad) Bismillahir Rahmanir Raheem. Mr. Presiding Member, I think it is the duty of the Representatives of the people to clearly state in this House the sentiments of the people whom they represent. So, as someone who represents the Muslim people of the Digamadulla District, I would like to categorically state in this House that in the history of this country no Muslim leader or no Muslim representative has ever supported separatism or condoned terrorism. We have always empathized with the sentiments of the Tamil-speaking people. But, we have categorically gone against separatist tendencies and also vehemently opposed terrorism. As history has recorded in this country, after the advent of militancy among the Tamil people, the Muslims have suffered as much as the Sinhalese people in this country. But, we must also understand and acknowledge that no Sinhala leader in this country has ever supported separatism. No one has supported separatism. But, their acts of omission have today led to the Tamil people to espousing separatism. We know the history of this country. We know that when we came together as one nation to win Independence in this country, we spoke of a

Sri Lankan nationalism. We spoke of a Sri Lankan identity and it is the political positions that we have taken that have been fundamentally divisive. Having come together to attain Independence as one nation, how did we come today to dividing ourselves on linguistic and ethnic lines and espousing various nationalism? This is something that we need to address because it is always very easy to keep on blaming the Opposition. We know that the late Mr. S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike was the first politician to espouse federalism in this country. In 1926, when he set forth on this soil as an Oxford educated member of the elite of this country, he espoused a federal solution to this country. But, when he was at the zenith of his political power, he was basically forced to articulate against it in 1956. Thirty years after having first sown the seed of federalism, he opposed it because of the political compulsions of that day. .. ( ) ( .. - ) (The Hon. H.R. Mithrapala - Minister of Consumer Affairs)

That is, the Bandaranaike-Chelvanayakam Pact. . . . ( . . . ) (The Hon. A. M. M. Naoshaad) That is what I am coming to; hold on. Then, the issues of nationalism started, as the Hon. Minister rightly said, with the first Bandaranaike-Chelvanayakam Pact, where the majority agreed to disagree. Then, we had the Dudley Senanayake-Chelvanayakam Agreement. Again we agreed to disagree. Then, we had the J. R. Jayewardene-Amirthalingam Understanding. There also we agreed to disagree. It is these political positions and the wavering of the majority that led the Tamil people to say, Look, this is not going to happen. They are not going to accommodate us into a Sri Lankan nationality. Therefore, we need to espouse our own cause and we want a nation of our own. [Interruption.] Do not interrupt me. I am coming to that. I speak here as a Sri Lankan. So, listen to me. Then we had the episode of the Premadasa regime, the Wijetunga regime and then again, a Bandaranaike came before this country and asked for a mandate of peace. Having got a mandate of peace and having made an attempt at negotiating peace, we went back to war. Again in 2001, the Hon. Ranil Wickremasinghe went before the people on a mandate of peace, came to power and signed a CFA which we put all the blame on. But, we must understand it is only the events after the CFA that laid the ground work for the international support this Government has got after commencing this war. If we are to blame this war on, we have to blame it on all the Sinhala political leaders who ruled this country since

Independence. It cannot be left to one person. You cannot say that the UNP is the cause for all these. The SLFP has ruled this country, the UNP has ruled this country and they have sown the seeds for what we have reaped. You shall reap what you sow. Now, having gone through all this and having officially lost over 70,000 lives - I am sure unofficially that it has to be more than 100,000 - we have come to a situation where we are now caught up in a fixed mindset. What the late Hon. S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike strived to achieve in 1956 - he sowed the Sinhala nationalist seed in 1956 - he had to eventually pay with his life. Today, His Excellency the President has achieved that. What the Horagolla Wallawwa could not achieve, the Medamulana Walawwa has achieved. All credit goes to him but having achieved that and taken the Sinhala people to this mindset, how do you reconcile to form a Sri Lankan identity? I have spoken of this before. You have on your side over 13 Members of Parliament - Ministers and Deputy Ministers - who are Muslims. You have over eight or nine representatives of the Tamil people. So, you have in all over 20 Members of Parliament who belong to the minority communities. Despite that, we all know that the divisive mindset of the minorities have been clearly demonstrated in every election that has taken place after the advent of this Government. Why? When you have so many representatives on that side who are doing so much of development work - in fact, they feel that it is a waste of time on our part to be sitting on this side and talking while they are developing the community - I give credit to that. But, with all that development and all the power that they have in their hands, they cannot change the mindset of the people who brought them to this House. Except for three Muslim Members of Parliament who sit on that side - the Hon. A. H. M. Fowzie, the Hon. (Mrs.) Ferial Ismail Ashraff and the Hon. A. L. M. Athaullah - the rest of them came from this side. The rest of them were voted to power by the people who felt that the grouping that has come to power is not going to solve this problem. Now, having convinced them to sit on that side and serve the people and if service is what changes the peoples mindset, it has not worked. We have found that at every election, the majority of the minority has voted against this Government, not because they do not want development, not because they do not want jobs, not because they hate those representatives. No, that is because they still do not feel that this Government is capable of taking them into a Sri Lankan identity. They fear; they fear the unknown; they do not know what is in store.

We say that this Eelam War IV is a humanitarian effort. Yes, Mavil Aru was one. But, what happened between Mavil Aru and now is a pure war. We have nothing against it. Force has to be met with force. There is absolutely no problem. But, we are now in a huge

humanitarian crisis because we dismiss numbers and say, No, in 56 square miles you cannot have 300,000 people. It is immaterial. There can be 30 people, but they are all human lives. So, you have to weed out the LTTE from the Tamil people. You cannot brand every Tamil a member of the LTTE. We have lessons in history. We have lessons in the history of the world in conflict resolution. Take the example of Ireland. The IRA was a terrorist organization, branded as a terrorist organization and represented politically by Sinn Fein. Sinn Fein was their political arm. But, that did not stop the British Government from talking to Sinn Fein. They did not say, Because you are representatives of the IRA, we cannot talk to you; you are as good as the IRA. No, you cannot speak to splinters of the major group and say, They are the representatives of the Tamils. We can speak to them because they are on our side and these people sit in the Opposition camp; they represent the LTTE. So, we cannot talk to them. They represent the Tamil people as much as we represent the people of our area. So, if you need to talk about a problem that affects our people, you need to talk to us.

We have been talking. The peace process has gone on for how long? For almost three years now; 104 sittings in two years. The TNA has not sat in; the Tamil people have not sat in to talk of a solution to this problem. So, when do we start talking? Do we start talking after we have killed each and every member of the LTTE or do we start talking after we have finished off the TNA as well? No. Then, whom do you talk to? Do you talk to the people who are in those concentration camps? No way! You have to talk to the people who sit in this House as the Representatives of the people who have voted them to power. Whether the LTTE picked them to come to Parliament is a different issue, but it is the Tamil people who voted for them. So, you need to take the Representatives of the Tamil people into your confidence and start talking. I am sure they are not going to carry a suicide kit or a grenade into Temple Trees. No way! But, yes, they will not sit and start nodding for everything that the Government proposes. No way, because they represent the people. So, if we cannot change our mindset and think okay, now we have finished the war, for once, we are in a positive mindset, we have a superiority complex now. For all these years, all these Sinhala leaders kept us in an inferiority mindset. Now, His Excellency the President has brought us to a superiority mindset and therefore, we shall now talk peace on our terms. This is what has brought us to this position. The fighters of the LTTE were not produced out of machines; they were not thrown out of a machine produced by Prabhakaran. All these suicide bombers were not robots. They were human beings. They were driven to a point where they felt convinced that what they were doing was right. So, how

do you change that mindset? How do you convince the Tamil people to forget the past because we have to forget the past? The past is always before us because all we can talk of is the past. But, it is the lessons of the past that we have to learn from. We have to take them in, absorb them and then sincerely make an effort at changing the mindset of the people whom you represent, the people whom you have taken to the zenith and those who are now downtrodden. We know that there was a time when the Tamil people felt that they were very strong because the LTTE was very strong. Today, they feel very meek because the LTTE is weak. But, that does not disqualify them from being citizens of this country. So, I appeal to this Government to basically start talking even now, by understanding their mindset, by understanding the root cause, to the Representatives of the Tamil people and understand what needs to be done at least now to ensure that we build a Sri Lankan nationality, a Sri Lankan identity and not leave room for the seeds of separatism to be sown once again. It can be among the Muslims, it can be among the Tamils and it can even be among the Sinhalese because we know that before we gained Independence, the Sinhala race was a divided race in this country. We had the up-country Sinhalese; we had the Karawa caste; we had all the caste divisions and it is Independence that brought us together. In fact, the Kandyans espoused federalism long before everybody else because they felt that the foreigners were not giving them their due place. So, as long as there is a reason, as long as the people feel that there is a reason, they will always go behind that. Therefore, take that reason out and let us all work towards forging a Sri Lankan identity. Thank you.

WRITTEN ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS : : COMBINED POSTAL SERVICE PROMOTIONS : FORMAL APPOINTMENT LETTERS

asked the Minister of Posts and Telecommunication, : (a) Will he submit to this House the seniority list pertaining to the posts of Chief Post Master, Control Assistant, Post Office Investigation Inspector and Post Office Accounts Inspector of category B of Grade III of Group A of the Combined Postal Service for the period from 01.01.2001 to 31.12.2006? (b) Will he inform this House of the backdating post, the date on which the vacancy occurred, the way in which it occurred and the name of the officer who should be appointed with relevance to the filling of vacancies that existed in the post of Chief Post Master and Control Assistant during the period from 01.01.2001 to 31.12.2006?

(c) Is he aware that although they have been promoted to the post of Chief Post Master of category B of Grade III of Group A with effect from 17.06.2002, formal appointment letters have not been issued to them by the Secretary to the Public Service Commission? (d) Will he direct the relevant authorities to issue the formal appointment letters to them immediately as some of them have already been sent on retirement after reaching sixty years of age? (e) If not, why?
( ) ( - , ) (The Hon. Mahinda Wijesekara - Minister of Posts and Telecommunication)
: : PROMOTIONS IN COMBINED POSTAL SERVICE : INTERVIEWS 0955/08 2.

asked the Minister of Posts and Telecommunication, : (a) Is he aware that the interviews for promoting employees to Class A III B of the Combined Postal Officers Service were conducted at the Postal Headquarters on 12.10.2005 and 13.10.2005? (b) Will he state the names and official addresses of Chief Post Masters, Administrative Assistants, Post Office Investigation Inspectors and Post Office Accounts Inspectors of Class A III B who attended that interview?

(c) Will he submit to this House, separately in re-spect of each officer, the marks obtained by each of them at the interview for seniority, service record, and skills/ personality displayed at the interview? (d) If not, why?
: MAHARAGAMA URBAN COUNCIL : ASSESSMENT TAX 0907/08 3. ( ) (The Hon. Sunil Handunnetti) (2) : () (i) 2008 ; (ii) ; (iii) ; ? () ? () ? () ? , : () (i) 2008 , (ii) , (iii) ? () ? () , ?

() , ? asked the Minister of Local Government and Provincial Councils, : (a) Will he inform this House (i) of the percentages of rates to be charged for the year 2008, as approved by the Urban Council of Maharagama; (ii) of the basis on which those rates were deter-mined; and (iii) whether the valuation officers of the said ur-ban council have visited the entire area and obtained a correct valuation? (b) Will he admit that this value of rates is an exor-bitant amount? (c) If so, will he state the steps that will be taken to rectify it? (d) If not, why?
( - , ) (The Hon. Janaka Bandara ThennakoonMinister of Local Government and Provincial Councils) () .

(a) Yes. (i) 7per cent of the annual value of residential property. 10 per cent of the annual value of commercial property. (ii) Based on the annual value of the property. (iii) No. Officials of the Valuation Department have visited the entire area and done this valuation. (b) No. (c) Does not arise.
: AVISSAWELLA URBAN COUNCIL : ASSESSMENT TAX 0908/08 4. ( ) (The Hon. Sunil Handunnetti) (2) : () (i) 2008 ;
() , ? asked the Minister of Local Government and Provincial Councils, :

(a) Will he inform this House (i) of the percentages of rates to be charged for the year 2008, as approved by the Urban Council of Avissawella; (ii) of the basis on which those rates were deter-mined; and (iii) whether the valuation officers of the said ur-ban council have visited the entire area and obtained a correct valuation? (b) Will he admit that this value of rates is an exor-bitant amount? (c) If so, will he state the steps that will be taken to rectify it? (d) If not, why?

(a) Yes. (i)* House property of which the annual value is Rs. 500 or below is exempted from paying taxes. * 10 per cent of the annual value of all other house property. * 15 Per cent of the annual value of every Com-mercial property. (ii) Based on the annual value of the property. (iii) Officials of the Valuation Department have visited the entire area and done a correct valuation. (b) No. (c) Does not arise. (d) Does not arise.
: SRI JAYAWARDENEPURA MUNICIPAL COUNCIL : ASSESS-MENT TAX 0909/08 5. ( ) (The Hon. Sunil Handunnetti) (2) : () (i) 2008 ; (ii) ;

(iii) ; ? () ? () ? () ? , : () (i) 2008 , (ii) , (iii) ? () ? () , ? () , ? asked the Minister of Local Government and Provincial Councils : (a) Will he inform this House (i) of the percentages of rates to be charged for the year 2008, as approved by the Municipal Coun-cil of Sri Jayawardenapura; (ii) of the basis on which those rates were deter-mined; and (iii) whether the valuation officers of the said urban council have visited the entire area and ob-tained a correct valuation? (b) Will he admit that this value of rates is an exorbi-tant amount? (c) If so, will he state the steps that will be taken to rectify it? (d) If not, why?

(a) No. (i) 7 per cent of the annual value of the residential land and bare and the 18 per cent of every property other than residential and bare land. (ii) Based on the annual value of the property. : MORATUWA MUNICIPAL COUNCIL : ASSESSMENT TAX 0910/08 6. ( ) (The Hon. Sunil Handunnetti) (2) : () (i) 2008 ; (ii) ; (iii) ; ? () ? () ? () ?

() , ? asked the Minister of Local Government and Provincial Councils: (a) Will he inform this House (i) of the percentages of rates to be charged for the year 2008, as approved by the Municipal Coun-cil of Moratuwa; (ii) of the basis on which those rates were deter-mined; and (iii) whether the valuation officers of the said Mu-nicipal Council have visited the entire area and obtained a correct valuation? (b) Will he admit that this value of rates is an exorbi-tant amount? (c) If so, will he state the steps that will be taken to rectify it? (d) If not, why?

() () (a) Yes. (i) 8 per cent of the annual value of every house property. 12 per cent of the annual value of every com-mercial, industrial, state, non-state property other than house property. 20 per cent of the annual value of bare land and buildings under construction. (ii) Based on the annual value of the property. (iii) officials of the Department of Valuation and not the valuers in the municipal council have visited the relevant areas and done this valua-tion. (b) No. (c) Does not arise. (d) Does not arise.
DEHIWELA - MT. LAVINIA MUNICIPAL COUNCIL : ASSESSMENT TAX 0911/08 7. ( ) (The Hon. Sunil Handunnetti) (2) : () (i) - 2008 ; (ii) ;

asked the Minister of Local Government and Provincial Councils, : (a) Will he inform this House (i) of the percentages of rates to be charged for the year 2008, as approved by the Municipal Council of Dehiwela Mt. Lavinia; (ii) of the basis on which those rates were deter-mined; and (iii) whether the valuation officers of the said Minicipal council have visited the entire area and obtained a correct valuation? (b) Will he admit that this value of rates is an exor-bitant amount? (c) If so, will he state the steps that will be taken to rectify it? (d) If not, why?

() (a) Yes. (i) *30 per cent annual value of trade and commercial property. *6 per cent of annual value of property other thaen trade and commercial property (including houses) 6 per cent of annual value of bare land. (ii) Based on the annual value of the property. (iii) A property within the municipal council area is assessed by the Government Valuer in the Department of Valuation. Every property in the area is assessed by engaging officials of this Department.. (b) No. (c) Does not arise.

( ) (The Hon. Sunil Handunnetti) (2) : () (i) 2008 ; (ii) ; (iii) ; ? () ? () ? () ? , : () (i) 2008 , (ii) , (iii) ? () ? () , ? () , ? asked the Minister of Local Government and Provincial Councils, : (a) Will he inform this House (i) of the percentages of rates to be charged for the year 2008, as approved by the Municipal Council of Colombo; (ii) of the basis on which those rates were deter-mined; and (iii) whether the valuation officers of the said Mu-nicipal Council have visited the entire area and obtained a correct valuation? (b) Will he admit that this value of rates is an exorbitant amount?
(c) If so, will he state the steps that will be taken to rec-tify it?

(i) * 35 per cent of the annual value of business property in developed areas. 25 per cent of the annual value of residential property in developed areas. * 25 per cent of the business property in under-developed areas. 15 per cent of the residential property in under - developed areas. (ii) Based on the annual value of the property. (iii) Yes. (b) No. (c) Does not arise. (d) Does not arise.
